attributes.title: Implicit attitudes toward visible and invisible disabilities

q3.value: This is a pilot test to determine the best words to use for an IAT in which we measure implicit attitudes toward visible and invisible disability.

q4.value: This is an exploratory pilot test. We hope to extra a four factor solution in a principle components analysis to discover the words that best align with visible and invisible abilities and disabilities. We will also examine the tested words for face validity and examine means the ratings. Through discussion, based on the factor analysis and descriptives, we will decide which words to include in an IAT.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q9.value: words to rate are randomized within a block (ability or disability). The disability and ability blocks are also presented in random order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data are being collected through social networks of the primary student researcher. The faculty advisor will also collect some data through his courses.

q14.value: We hope to collect a minimum of 200 participants. We need 20 total words with four factors, thus 200 would provide 10x the number of variables we hope to retain.

q15.value: We will stop when we hit or exceed our target N.

question.value: We will run a principle components analysis to find the words in each category that most strongly load onto each one of the four factors (ability/disability, visible/invisible).

q21.value: We will run a parallel analysis to determine the number of retained factors of the PCA.

q24.value: We include demographics in the survey, but have no plans to examine these.

attributes.title: Moving from evidence to decisions when making recommendations in healthcare: a protocol of an analysis of clinical practice guidelines guidance documents
attributes.description: The process of moving from evidence to decisions (EtD) represents a cornerstone within guideline development methods and must be guided by a framework outlining the factors to be considered to arrive at a decision. Various multicriteria EtD frameworks have been launched by international organization devoted to guidelines development. Nevertheless, the extent of use of the EtD frameworks for guideline development has not yet been evaluated systematically. This study aims to identify and describe the processes and frameworks suggested for formulating recommendations in guidance documents for clinical practice guidelines development. We will use a descriptive analysis approach.

summary.value:
Note: this protocol has not been registered anywhere. 

Abstract

Background: The process of moving from evidence to decisions (EtD) represents a cornerstone within guideline development methods and must be guided by a framework outlining the factors to be considered to arrive at a decision. Various multicriteria EtD frameworks have been launched by international organization devoted to guidelines development. Nevertheless, the extent of use of the EtD frameworks for guideline development has not yet been evaluated systematically. This study aims to identify and describe the processes and frameworks suggested for formulating recommendations in guidance documents for clinical practice guidelines development. We will use a descriptive analysis approach. 

Methods/Design: We will systematically analyze guidance documents produced by worldwide institutions responsible for guideline development published in the last decade. Websites of the organizations will be inspected to identify all available documents related to guideline development. We will search the Guidelines International Network (G-I-N) website, MEDLINE via PubMed, and The Cochrane Methodology Register. Pairs of independent researchers will select and extract data. A data collection form has been developed and piloted. This form collects information on the main characteristics of the guidance document, the management of conflict of interests, the different factors and the processes taken into account, and the potential frameworks suggested to formulate recommendations. If present, we will specifically collect information about the criteria of the GRADE-EtD frameworks. 

Discussion: A complete analysis of the criteria used by organizations to move from evidence to recommendations in guideline development is needed, since a growing diversity of criteria has become evident nowadays. To our knowledge, this study represents the first systematic analysis of the EtD frameworks available for guidelines development. This protocol is developed by some members of the GRADE Working Group for the study of the GRADE-EtD frameworks, and is subscribed as the first project in such scientific group. Results from this research will contribute to more systematic, transparent, and explicit guidance about the comprehensive process of moving from evidence to decisions, and might lead to guidelines that are more trustworthy. This will enable guideline developers to improve quality of healthcare.


Keywords: Practice guidelines; Decision Making; Evidence-Based Practice; Methods

Keywords: Practice guidelines; Decision Making; Evidence-Based Practice; Methods

attributes.title: Mental health project during the COVID-19 epidemic period
attributes.description:
This is an open-ended project. We aim to investigate the social-psychological factors that may affect people during the COVID-19 epidemic period. By a two-wave longitudinal design, we plan to recruit Chinese participants from the internet and collect following data.
1.	Wake Forest Physician Trust Scale
2.	Physician-patient Trust Scale
3.	DOSPERT scale
4.	Faking news scale
5.	Public confidence scale for outbreaks
6.	Public perceived control for outbreaks
7.	Trust to family, neighbors, strangers, doctors, governments, etc.
8.	Consumer confidence index during the outbreak
9.	Ability and warmth scale
10.	One-shot trust game and one-shot Chicken game
The results will contribute to public health and epidemiological research.

attributes.title: Pre-registered Replication of Han & Kahn (2017)
attributes.description: A replication of the Han & Kahn (2017) study which found a link between insecure attachment, problems with emotional regulation and disordered eating in college aged men and women.

item1.value:
The researchers found that attachment anxiety was associated with binge eating via emotional reactivity, and
attachment avoidance was associated with restricted eating via emotional cutoff, in both college women and men.

item2.value:
This research was the first of it's kind to clearly demonstrate effects of attachment anxiety and attachment avoidance on eating behaviours (Han & Kahn 2017) following only one similar finding (Zachrisson & Skarderud, 2010). Previously this finding has been somewhat elusive with other studies showing either no effect of attachment avoidance on eating behaviour (e.g., Wilkinson, Rowe & Millings, 2019; ) or a very small effect that showed a similar pathway for attachment anxiety and avoidance (rather than a differential one) (e.g., Faber, Dubè & Knauper, 2018). 
Given the clinical applications that the research has it is important to replicate it to ensure it is genuine effect before psychologists use this research within a practical setting (i.e., tailoring differential support based on attachment orientation (e.g., Sockalingam & Hawa, 2016)
Refereces

Cortés-García, L., Takkouche, B., Seoane, G., & Senra, C. (2019). Mediators linking insecure attachment to eating symptoms: A systematic review and meta-analysis. PLOS ONE, 14(3), e0213099. 

Sockalingam, S., & Hawa, R. (2016). Attachment Style in Bariatric Surgery Care: A Case Study. In Improving Patient Treatment with Attachment Theory (pp. 145-154). Springer, Cham.

Tasca, G., Szadkowski, L., Illing, V., Trinneer, A., Grenon, R., & Demidenko, N. et al. (2009). Adult attachment, depression, and eating disorder symptoms: The mediating role of affect regulation strategies. Personality And Individual Differences, 47(6), 662-667.
Wilkinson, L., Rowe, A., & Millings, A. (2019). Disorganized attachment predicts body mass index via uncontrolled eating. International Journal Of Obesity, 44(2), 438-446.

item3.value: The indirect effect from attachment anxiety to emotional reactivity to binge eating is .16, from attachment anxiety to emotional cut off to binge eating is .04, from attachment anxiety to emotional reactivity to restricted eating is .09 and from attachment anxiety to emotional cut off to restricted eating is .03.   The indirect effect from attachment avoidance to emotional reactivity to binge eating is -.03, from attachment avoidance to emotional cut off to binge eating is .2, from attachment avoidance to emotional reactivity to restricted eating is .02 and from attachment avoidance to emotional cut off to restricted eating is .11.  Attachment anxiety was positively associated with emotional reactivity, and attachment avoidance was negatively associated with emotional reactivity, R2 = .38. Emotional cut- off (R2 = .47) was positively associated with both attachment anxiety and attachment avoidance. The stronger paths by far were between (a) attachment anxiety and emotional reactivity and (b) attachment avoidance and emotional cutoff. Binge eating (R2 = .20) was positively associated with both emotional reactivity and emotional cutoff. Finally, restricted eating (R2 = .07) was positively associated with both emotional cutoff and emotional reactivity.

item4.value: The confidence interval for the attachment anxiety, emotional reactivity, and binge eating pathway*** is CI 99% [.07, .23] for women, and CI 99% [.14, .48] for men. The confidence interval for the attachment anxiety, emotional cut-off, and binge eating pathway is CI 99% [.01, .08] for women, and CI 99% [-.03, .04] for men.  The confidence interval for the attachment anxiety, emotional reactivity, and restricted eating pathway is CI 99% [.02, .17] for women, and CI 99% [–.08, .25] for men.  The confidence interval for the attachment anxiety, emotional cut-off, and restricted eating pathway is CI 99% [.00, .05] for women, and CI 99% [–.03, .09] for men.  The confidence interval for the attachment avoidance, emotional reactivity, and binge eating pathway is CI 99% [–.06, .00] for men, and CI 99% for men.  The confidence interval for the attachment avoidance, emotional cut-off, and binge eating pathway is CI 99% [.13, .27] for women, and CI 99% [–.10, .16] for men.  The confidence interval for the attachment avoidance, emotional reactivity, and restricted eating pathway is CI 99% [–.04, .00] for women, and CI 99% [–.07, .03] for men.  The confidence interval for the attachment avoidance, emotional cut-off, and restricted eating pathway*** is CI 99% [.05, .18] for women, and CI 99% [.02, .28] for men. *** Indicates the pathways that the original researchers were interested in to support their hypothesis.

item5.value: The final sample included 944 participants- 744 (79%) women and 200 (21%) men.

item8.value: Psychology students recruited from the psychology department research participation pool.

item11.value: The materials used are well established, published, and validates within the psychological community. Furthermore, both the original study and the replication study will be conducted within Western, English speaking communities.

item12.value: Away from the participants, because the study will be conducted online.

item13.value: Not applicable, as there are no separate experimental conditions.

item14.value: Experimenter will be aware of the overall hypotheses, but this shouldn't impact the results as the study will be conducted online.

item15.value: The minimum sample required would be 462.

item16.value: According to Fritz and MacKinnon (2007) a sample of around 400-500 would be needed to have sufficient power to detect a small effect sizes, which is what we are aiming for.

item24.value: The aim of the replication will be obscured within the information sheet and consent form to minimise demand characteristics; however it is unclear whether the original researchers did this.

item25.value: I will email the original researchers to ask to use the same instructions, and get the consent form as close as possible. This cannot be exactly the same as the studies will use different ethics boards, which means they may need to include different information. A demand awareness question will also be used to assess whether the participants were able to guess what the aim of the study was.

item26.value: The replication will use the same exclusion criteria as the original study, in which answers which appear to be selected at random, responses where more than half of the survey is incomplete, or in those who don't provide sufficient demographic material.

item27.value: The replication will use the same analysis plan as the original, where the AMOS add on to SPSS will be used to complete a structural equation model.

item28.value: Findings that the same pathways outlined within the original study are significant, and have similar effect sizes.

registration_responses.item1:
The researchers found that attachment anxiety was associated with binge eating via emotional reactivity, and
attachment avoidance was associated with restricted eating via emotional cutoff, in both college women and men.
registration_responses.item2:
This research was the first of it's kind to clearly demonstrate effects of attachment anxiety and attachment avoidance on eating behaviours (Han & Kahn 2017) following only one similar finding (Zachrisson & Skarderud, 2010). Previously this finding has been somewhat elusive with other studies showing either no effect of attachment avoidance on eating behaviour (e.g., Wilkinson, Rowe & Millings, 2019; ) or a very small effect that showed a similar pathway for attachment anxiety and avoidance (rather than a differential one) (e.g., Faber, Dubè & Knauper, 2018). 
Given the clinical applications that the research has it is important to replicate it to ensure it is genuine effect before psychologists use this research within a practical setting (i.e., tailoring differential support based on attachment orientation (e.g., Sockalingam & Hawa, 2016)
Refereces

Cortés-García, L., Takkouche, B., Seoane, G., & Senra, C. (2019). Mediators linking insecure attachment to eating symptoms: A systematic review and meta-analysis. PLOS ONE, 14(3), e0213099. 

Sockalingam, S., & Hawa, R. (2016). Attachment Style in Bariatric Surgery Care: A Case Study. In Improving Patient Treatment with Attachment Theory (pp. 145-154). Springer, Cham.

Tasca, G., Szadkowski, L., Illing, V., Trinneer, A., Grenon, R., & Demidenko, N. et al. (2009). Adult attachment, depression, and eating disorder symptoms: The mediating role of affect regulation strategies. Personality And Individual Differences, 47(6), 662-667.
Wilkinson, L., Rowe, A., & Millings, A. (2019). Disorganized attachment predicts body mass index via uncontrolled eating. International Journal Of Obesity, 44(2), 438-446.

attributes.title: A Crucial Moment in Defense: An RCT of Counsel at First Appearance
attributes.description: Using an RCT, this project analyzes the effect of counsel at first appearance on recidivism, failure to appear, and type and amount of bond.

q1.value: A Crucial Moment in Defense: An RCT of Counsel at First Appearance

q2.value: Georges Naufal, D. James Greiner, Renee Danser

q3.value: The bond hearing determines whether and the conditions under which a defendant avoids pretrial incarceration. Most defendants, however, face a judge alone at this crucial juncture. This project proposes to use a randomized controlled trial (“RCT”) to explore whether the provision of counsel at first appearance (“CAFA”) produces lower bond amounts for defendants and increases the likelihood of being granted a personal recognizance bond instead of a financial bond. In other words, we propose to test whether randomly assigning CAFA reduces the likelihood of pretrial incarceration. In turn, we will assess how this shapes the likelihood of defendants returning to court and whether this sort of policy is financially beneficial for local jurisdictions, who would conceivably save considerable money in jail costs with fewer defendants incarcerated pretrial.

q4.value: Non-financial bail rates are expected to be higher when counsel is present at first appearance. Bail amounts are expected to be smaller when counsel is present at first appearance.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Data will be collected for one full year intended to align with the beginning of randomization. At the beginning of every month, a schedule of randomized days for the month will be provided to the county and attorneys who will be representing defendants at their first appearance. Randomization involves days on which services (counsel) are provided rather than specific persons into groups.  We test for balance using the day of the week and also the week of the year. We also use the day of the week (and month) as a strata variable and randomize across strata to offer everyone on a specific day counsel or not pending the assignment. On the days of the treatment, all defendants will be represented by counsel.

q9.value: Randomization involves days on which services (counsel) are provided rather than specific persons into groups.  We test for balance using the day of the week and also the week of the year. We also use the day of the week (and month) as a strata variable and randomize across strata to offer everyone on a specific day counsel or not pending the assignment. Randomization will be created through the randomize command in Stata.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data will consist of jail, court, and case-level data from the county. Data will be pulled from the court system from the county. Data will include all those arrested during the period of the data collection. There is no recruitment nor payment for participation. All arrestees are eligible to be part of the study.  Data collection starts in early 2020 and lasts for a year. 

Data will also be collected from attorneys during magistration. Each attorney will fill a brief sheet which includes attorney information, how many defendants have they counseled, the state identification number, and comments/notes from the magistration.

q13.value: There will be about 26-day clusters for each day of the week for the treatment group and the same number for the control group. All arrestees getting magistrated on the treatment days will be enrolled in the study. We expect an average of about 20 defendants to be magistrated per day (seven days a week) for a total of about 7,300 per year. The treatment and control groups are each expected to have about 3,650 defendants.

q14.value: The sample includes all defendants who get magistrated during one full year.

q15.value: Data collection will stop after 365 days.

question.value:
Outcome measures include primary outcomes: bail type and bail amount; and secondary outcomes: recidivism and failure to appear rates, disposition and sentencing outcomes. 

Covariates include case and defendant level variables such as judge and attorney effects, the severity of the offense, type of offense, criminal history, and demographics of the defendants.

Rely on assignment-mechanism based tests (such as permutation tests and comparisons of means); this approach allows us to avoid assumptions regarding functional form and outcome distributions but imposes a price in terms of loss of precision. Another approach would be linear regression to account for covariates for better precision of estimates.

attributes.title: BHT for Chronic pharyngitis A systematic review protocol
attributes.description: Chronic pharyngitis is a common disease with a dry throat, sore throat, pharyngeal itching, dry cough and difficulty in swallowing, bringing inconvenience to patients’ daily life.BHT（Banxia-Houpo-Tang） has proven to be effective in the treatment of chronic pharyngitis, yet its real extent is nWe will search for electronic databases both English and Chinese from inception to December 2019. Two experienced researchers select the qualified articles from：The Cochrane Library, EBM Reviews, OVID, Web of Science, PubMed, Chinese National Knowledge Infrastructure (CNKI), China Academic Journal Network Publishing Database (CAJD), China Biomedical Literature database (CBM), VIP Database for Chinese Technical Periodicals (VIP). Journal Integration Platform and WAN FANG Database. We select the appropriate searching language. The primary outcome was remission rate, and the secondary outcomes include clinical symptoms, clinical examination, adverse event. Data extraction and quality assessment will be conducted by two experienced researchers independently. Data analysis and the risk of bias assessment will be determined by RevMan 5.3 software.ot well understood.
